author: Adam White
title: Great controller with Windows 10
content:
First, let me state that I do not use this in wireless mode.  There is no need for what I am doing.  I am sitting in front of my computer, and my keyboard has a USB port in it.  This keeps the controller powered, and connected, and there is no wireless lag even possible.  This is important for games like CSGO, etc.  So, that is what I use.

Setting this up in windows 10 is as easy as plugging a USB cable into the controller and plugging the controller into the PC.  That was it.  Then, I started using it on games immediately.  It is great, it really makes PC games feel more like Xbox One games, but, I like the PC games much more.  So, now I use the controller for the majority of the things that I do in the game, but I still have the keyboard for the more complex games where there isn't enough buttons on the controller like "Elite Dangerous" which is one of my current favorites.

For now, I use the two analog sticks for normal flying, and for landing, and they are great.  The digital up/down/left/right is my throttle in normal flight and my forward back, left right in landing.  The triggers are obviously for guns, and the other buttons do common functions.  It makes playing the game a lot easier than using the mouse and keyboard.  While, I agree there are games that the mouse is better for, it is nice to have the option.

I opted for the brand name controller after hearing people having issues with the knock-offs.  I also opted for the wired simply out of simplicity and not wanting the possibility of introducing wireless lag.  That said, I couldn't connect wirelessly as-is, it requires an adapter to use this wireless, not sure why as it is Bluetooth, but that seems to be the requirement.  Maybe I am doing something wrong, not sure, but I wasn't able to get it to work.  However, using it wired is as simple as plug and play.  I couldn't be happier.

author: Kevin Larson
title: No Rumble on Win10
content:
Sigh.  Still no rumble support on PC since input driver update.

After a Windows update that I received a few months back, my trusty old USB wired Xbox 360 controller stopped working properly.  The controller itself was fine, as it still works normally on my windows 8 PC - but on my Win 10 machines some features - rumble most importantly - just won't work any longer.

It sucks that I've become so used to rumble as I know many prefer to play with it turned off.  But for me, it provides useful haptic feedback that helps me more easily time my button presses in games like Rocket League.

Anyway, in an attempt to get the rumble feature working again I purchased a new, Xbox One S controller......whiiiiich has the exact same issues as the 360 controller...

It looks like Microsoft switched to a new controller input driver recently which could be the cause for all of this madness.  But you would think that they'd test their new input driver for stability before pushing it out to the masses...

So basically just know that if you're buying this controller for PC, rumble WILL NOT work (regardless of whether it's connected with the wire or over Bluetooth) and regardless of whether or not your rumble preference is enabled on Steam.

TL;DR:
Just buy a PS4 Controller.  The PC drivers for it are handled through a 3rd party application which seems like a more reliable route since Microsoft has a tendency to break their own products with software updates.  Rumble works on the PS4 controllers and even works when they're connected over Bluetooth!

title: Works on windows w/ xbox usb dongle, USB cable, AND bluetooth!

Microsoft says you can connect to Windows 10 3 ways: 1) Bluetooth  2) Xbox USB Dongle  3) USB Cable.
I can't seem to get direct bluetooth to work with windows 10.  It works with another xbox one dongle I already had and it works with the USB cable.  But, I still can't confirm this works with bluetooth (b/c it doesn't work for me yet even after checking for updates).  I'm not sure if my PC is too old or if these have been over sold.  They work nicely aside from that, so still giving 4 stars.  I'd give 5 if the bluetooth would work natively.
UPDATE 1/15/2019!!  You *CAN* make these work with bluetooth natively in Windows 10.  The trick is when you click "Add bluetooth or other device" in the Control Panel, you must select "Bluetooth" not "Everything else" EVEN THOUGH the Xbox controller is mentioned on that list.  The "everything else" list is meant for Xbox controllers using the XBox wireless adapter.  Duh, kind of my fault / misread.  Attaching picture so others can learn from my mistake.
The controllers work pretty darn well.  Every so often if you are too far from the bluetooth dongle/antenna they can disconnect.  Luckily many windows games I'm playing recognize the disconnect and kind of wait for you to get it back.
5 Stars!

author: trombone
title: Best Controller on the Market Edited for Quality
content:
Love it for PC with the Bluetooth. Sticks are precise, bumpers are fixed, and the textured grip feels great in the hand. LB and RB now great for shifting in driving games; so easy to use. MS already spent millions designing the Xbone controller and the mid-term then this upgrade really were great enhancements. Actually I'd call the bumpers more a "fix" than an enhancement. They used to be awful. The Bluetooth is reliable and setup is easy. I use batteries and the controller is very efficient with them. The impulse triggers are great but unfortunately aren't implemented in many games. They are in Forza though. It doesn't only "feel" better but actually helps to play the game for instance if you want to modulate when you brake with ABS off. Same for helping to control acceleration.

PC you need USB and Xbox accessories app for global button mapping and firmware updates. So not often if at all.

There also were/are a ton of different special editions and colors for more $$$ and the Design Lab which is really cool but more $$$. Black and white are fantastic together in my book and cost the least. This latest "S" version feels like it is built much butter than the older versions.

Models:
1537
2013-15
* Intro Xbone controller
* Impulse triggers
* "Improved" D-Pad
* Better grip texture on sticks
* Less latency/faster response

1697
2015-16
* 3.5mm and headset jack on the bottom
* Can get wireless firmware updates on console
* Awful clicky and heavy bumpers that you have to push exactly right are fixed
* Sticks have more tension/resistance
* Buttons have more heft

1698
2015
* The Elite (no Bluetooth but rumor about 2nd generation in the works)

1708 (S)
2016
* Texture and color of plastic around logo is different and more integrated; matte instead of shiny
* Bluetooth
* Textured grip on the back. Again overall quality feels nicer I don't feel like I'm getting ripped off paying this much for a controller...bumpers and buttons feel better once more
* Thumbstick movement is steadier and smoother (more resistance; smoother circular rotation)
* Console owners have better range up to 40ft away
* Probably some of the what they learned designing the Elite trickled down to this model
 * They fixed the problem with white powder under the sticks after prolonged use

Edit: Left stick broke after a few months of use. Great controller, terrible build quality.

The controllers body was loose and creaked like an 18th century wood floor.  Within 8 months, the controller managed to develop stick drift on both sticks, left stick pulls top right, and right stick pulls bottom left, completely opposite directions of each other.  After going through 3 Microsoft agents, (one disconnected the call from me, one said they couldn't replace it, and the other spent 50 minutes to come to the same conclusion as the last one).  Buy a dualshock if you can tolerate the ergonomics, or purchase an aftermarket/moddable xbox controller instead of this chinesium trash.

Second major improvement is the texture of the whole controller, there is now a textured grip on the back of the handles which makes for holding it for long times much more comfortable. Also the new plastic has very smooth almost sand blasted feel to it that makes it less prone to fingerprints and just feels like a much nicer product because of it. author: shingmae
title: MUST READ
content:
PROS
1. It comes with everything you'll need in a carry case including batteries
2. Button mapping is easy to set and can be for the thumbsticks you click in or triggers you hold
3. There are four preloaded thumbstick sensitivity curve types to set and adjust
4. All three thumbstick sets glide smooth with the shell not grinding it. And the long type is way more accurate in sniping games
5. It has two different D-Pads one is good for quarter combo moves
6. The triggers have a deadzone tuning for a quicker or slower timing reaction every time you pull it
7. You can make the trigger and sticks swap sides when button mapping
8. The vibration can be adjusted for any motor and sets with the configuration you make
9. The Guide button brightness adjusting sets with the configuration you make
CONS
1. A analog stick in the controller can get loose and start drifting even though it's never been dropped
2. There isn't a real good grip on the convex thumbstick set like the other two sets
3. You can't combo button map to any button, trigger or thumbstick
4. You can't mirror map one trigger to the other trigger but can with thumbsticks
5. While setting your triggers deadzone the trigger doesn't vibrate to make it accurate
6. You can only invert the y axis of the thumbstick and not the x axis
7. There is no inner or outer deadzone settings for the thumbsticks to set like the triggers have
8. There is no x and y axis thumbstick sensitivity to adjust separately
9. You can't make your own thumbstick sensitivity curves and can only choose the preloaded ones

author: Amazon Customer
title: Know the differences in xbox controllers before you buy one.
content:
If you're interested in buying an xbox controller there's somethings you need to know. There are 2 versions of the x1 controller. There are several differences and you may want to choose which one you think you'll prefer. i'll refer to the 1st gen as 1st and the 2nd gen as 2nd

-1st gen has inferior connection, while the 2nd has further connection range and Bluetooth (this is not important)

-1st gen face buttons are sunk deeper into the controller, while the 2nd has much higher face buttons (i prefer 1st gen height)

-2nd gen has a coarse plastic grit on the back of the controller while 1st is smooth, this is not helpful in any way it simply irritates your hands at best.

-1st gen has a smoother plastic used all around the controller while the 2nd has less smooth plastic

-2nd gen bumpers are FAR SUPEROIR to 1st gen, the perfect amount of resistance to use. (one of the main problems with 1st gen x1 controllers)

-2nd gen does not require an accessory to use a microphone with you can plug in a microphone with just the controller it's self

-2nd gen controller has quality issues I ONLY HAVE ONE however, the controller i received has some strange issues when i play with it, the sides do not feel solid what so ever and the plastic is no sealed properly, also the sticks have difficulty clicking down when pushed to a certain angle. (i've dropped my 1st gen countless times and it still feels higher quality than my brand new 2nd gen)

I can conclude that both xbox1 controllers are superior to 360s however.

author: Jonathan Comstock
title: Great controller - Good quality!
content:
Product Arrived: 12/9/2017
Original Review: 1/1/2018
This controller works great! Just as good, or better than the original controller I got with my Xbox One. So far it is holding up my a lot of use without showing any signs of wear. I cannot comment on the claim of "Get up to twice the wireless range compared to previous Xbox One Controllers (tested using the Xbox One S Console)" - This is due to the fact that I never had range issues before with my original Xbox One controller. I can only say that, so far, I have had no range issues.

Pros:
Thumb-sticks feel great - with good grip and good movement.
Thumb-sticks also snap back to centered position as they should when released.
All the buttons have good responses and good feel to them.
The actual grip on the controller has some small bumps to help with grip. I find this to be especially nice if your hands are a little slick. (Could be from sweaty hands, or maybe putting hand lotion on before playing).
Overall quality of the material is good - feels like a very solid controller that should last awhile.

Cons:
I have not found any yet. If a issue does occur I will update this review!

Overall its a great controller, that should (hopefully) last me a long time!

The plus of this is that it's easily replaceable, the cons: cost, and that the overcharge protection is built into a proprietary charging cable instead of into the controller itself; so is the charging indictor. Lol what.

General build feels solid. The triggers feel great. L1 R1 are satisfying, and R2 L2 have deep play with good feeling resistance. The offset left analog isn't as bad as it felt on older Xbox controllers, I actually don't feel off using it.

Analog sticks show great sensitivity. I'm not sure if there is 6 axis tilt like the ds4. It doesn't show up in the windows test screen.

For Android it works a x input, plug and play. Windows 7 over been having spotty recognition by app, but the system registers it easily and detects presses, might just need an update.

At $43 plus another $20 for a battery it's barely 3 star. It feels and performs slightly better than a $20-30 generic. It's okay. 3 stars is based on it hopefully lasting years.

author: NBMTX
title: Okay and functional controller, but I have some nitpicks with it.
content:
I bought this controller for Windows. I use it via bluetooth. The controller itself is good in that it works, but it's 2018 and a rechargeable battery and cable is sold separately, even on this improved revision. It's a little crazy that it took a revision to allow it to work without a dongle for PC too... but at least it does now. For review purposes, for the product listed and nothing more, the controller is just okay, requires 2x AA batteries (first are included, at least), but it doesn't have a USB cable. It uses a micro USB connector, so hopefully you have one (long enough for your circumstances) handy. The wireless radio (maybe BT specific?) emits a very high pitched whine, but it's very dependent on direction, proximity, and ambient noise... and probably personal hearing too.

I don't prefer the texture given to the hard plastic of the back side of the controller, but it's not necessarily bad. this I'd probably like it if I didn't prefer the materials of another controller I own. I also don't prefer the domed buttons compared to flatter topped buttons. Those things are purely subjective, and not "bad"... and since I'm super nitpicking, I don't like the plastic it's made out of, but that's a silly remark, even if true.

Note: this was entirely my own fault, but when I first tried to use this controller I had enormous range problems. My motherboard has a wifi/bt card, but I use a wired connection, so I didn't have the antennas installed, and the connectivity was basically non existent. It paired, but had a range of maybe 1FT. The BT signal relies on the same antennas as wifi, which seems pretty obvious now, but I hadn't realized I hadn't installed the antennas since I last rebuilt my PC (since I wasn't really using them). Just a heads up.

Regarding BATTERIES: At MSRP, the controller and the official play and charge kit comes out to be somewhere around $84. There are slightly cheaper third party battery packs, though mainly due to the fact that they're often sold as 2 packs, but if they're anything like my older 360 battery pack, their lifetime endurance is questionable. Even the quoted playtime varies greatly in their product descriptions, so a 2 pack of third party batteries will quote 2x 12 hours, while the official single battery quotes 30 hours. I don't know if either of these numbers are accurate, but if nothing else, reviews suggest that the third party batteries are inconsistent, so I'm probably just going to (bc I haven't yet) pay the extra for the official one, and hope their QA is on point. No matter what, I think this is an obnoxious process to have to deal with. Even if replaceable batteries can be advantageous, not including one (at least in the revision) is BS to me.

As a complete rechargeable controller, with a cable to use for wired play, this is the most expensive normal controller for a console.

author: Lord Nazo
title: IMPORTANT!! READ THIS TO FIX STICK DRIFT BEFORE IT HAPPENS!
content:
If you're like me and you've never experienced stick drift until you got an Xbox One controller and used it for about 6 months while playing first-person shooters, you're probably back here on Amazon to get your next controller after succumbing to the futility of being unable to repair the first controller after watching countless YouTube videos or articles. Read below for the best fix to this issue.

Before you even USE the controller for the first time, open up the controller just so that you're able to remove the face plate and expose the circuit boards, and get some krazy glue or gorilla glue (any kind of glue that is durable and non-corrosive). Look on the left sides of the little metal boxes where the joysticks usually are on the controller and you'll notice some dark gray piece. THAT is what causes the almost inevitable stick drift that cannot be fully fixed later on without some advanced component replacement that involves soldering. You will want to glue that down into place (since Micro$oft uses cheap materials) by gluing around the sides of that little dark gray panel. I did this about a year ago and my controller has not encountered stick drift at all.

As for my review of the controller, despite being manufactured by Microsoft, this controller is far less durable than the Xbox 360 controller. I've owned four Xbox 360 controllers for over 10 years and they all still work to this very day with no issues.

author: Chicagoon
title: Good controller
content:
There was a huge PR campaign prior to the launch of the Xbox One controller claiming that many millions of dollars of research had gone into making the best controller ever paired with a console. I think this controller isn't that much better than the old Xbox 360 controller, and in fact it went back in a few areas.

I use my controllers via Bluetooth on the PC now that Windows 10 allows native Bluetooth connection. I've been getting perhaps 20 hours per set of batteries, which is easily half the life of what I got on 360. It's ridiculous how often I need batteries, to the point that I've had to get a quick-charge pack for my controllers so I stop going through batteries.

Aside from batteries, everything else about the controller is my favorite design in history- just like the 360 controller. I really do think this controller (both of them) are the best console controller ever designed... so long as you don't play games that require ultra-fast D-pad action. The D-pad, just like on 360, is still useless for fighting games. It's fine for menus and puzzle games, but you really have to get an arcade stick for fighting games. The short version is that the D-Pad is raised above the controller and made of one large, round piece of plastic. The best-ever controllers for fighting games hid most of the D-pad under the controller surface and only let the buttons poke through the plastic, ensuring you didn't accidentally roll your thumb against the wrong part of the pad. There's just no way for this D-pad design to equal the older design.

So this is a 5/5 controller for action games an so forth, but it's a 3/5 in terms of battery life and fighting games. I'll average that out to a 4/5. Frankly, if all you want is a great PC game pad, I'd still get an old 360 controller for the battery life. Used 360 controllers will offset the cost of a 360 wireless dongle to allows the pads to work on PC, so you won't lose money on the conversion either.

author: Justin
title: Great controller, with just a few issues.
content:
This controller is fantastic, a near-complete improvement upon the already-stellar Xbox 360 controller design. If you're gonna use it on PC, though, do yourself a favor, and make sure you get the wireless USB adapter for it, too. Besides unlocking all of the controller's features on PC(8 controllers can sync to a single adapter, and you can use the headsets and keyboards designed for the controller), the proprietary wireless signal protocol used is stronger, with a wider band.

What this means is that you'll have more reliable input with less latency, less input lag, and (so far for me) no issues with your character spinning around in-game as if they're possessed because your PC has decided your Bluetooth input from the controller just isn't that high of a priority.

author: A Harvey
title: I want my Xbox 360 controller back.
content:
When the disc drive on my Xbox 360 quit working, it was almost 10 years old. At that time, I was still using the controllers that had come with the 360 when I purchased it new. TEN. YEARS! Those things could survive a nuclear holocaust.

As for my Xbox 1 controllers, I have 2 controllers that don’t work so far (replaced the one that came with the Xbox 2 weeks in, and now <4 months in, the replacement is not working). These have not been thrown across the room or stepped on. They have fallen off the couch a few times (and by the way, every single time they do, the battery compartment flies open and the batteries shoot out). Again, we try not to let that happen but it’s not something that should be a problem for a decent controller. The first one, 2 buttons malfunctioned so I can’t even jump in Skyrim (Y button), and the left trigger gets stuck when a loose piece of plastic inside gets lodged underneath it. On my replacement, the right bumper somehow got stuck in the “on” position.

The quality of the Xbox 1 controllers I’ve gotten has been EXTREMELY subpar compared to what I’m used to. Seriously disappointed! And I checked on microsoft’s Support website and they said the one I bought January 1 is out of warranty, so now apparently I have to pay $50 to replace these faulty controllers. For the ridiculous amount of money consoles cost these days, you’d think they would come with good accessories.

I’m not saying don’t buy this, because you’ll probably have the same problem with every controller, but I’m just saying, be prepared to need a new controller every few months because Microsoft only cares about money and (apparently) not customer service or quality control.

author: kaleb
title: What Happened To Quality? Microsoft doesn't care anymore.
content: Microsofts Xbox 360 controllers were seemingly indestructible. They lasted for years and years, offering seemingly endless hours of play time and could even take pretty heavy abuses such as being thrown HARD on a concrete floor (I was rough with mine as a teen, something I have grown out of). These XBOX ONE controllers are extremely poor quality in comparison. The joysticks fail extremely fast. It's a bummer because the overall shape and redesigned triggers were a great modification from the 360's. The only problem really is the joysticks. You could look at them wrong and they will start to "drift" affecting your ability to play and enjoy your games. Your character will walk on their own without you even touching the controller after only a few months play time it seems. My first controller that came with my console lasted less than 4 months before it was causing serious interruption to proper movement in game. My next two each lasted about 6 months before developing the same issues. Aim and movement are key to pretty much any game. The controller will just endlessly scroll through "windows" in game on their own. This is a serious fail on Microsoft's part, especially seeing how Battle Royale style games have become increasingly popular during the XBOX ONE's lifetime, requiring near constant movement. These controllers should be cut down to half price because generic knock-offs at less than half the price are outperforming and outliving these controllers. It's sad, I still have a half dozen xbox 360 controllers that can still function better than these Xbox One controllers. Microsoft, if you design another controller ever again, remember to make it DURABLE, and nobody wants your extra fancy $160 Elite controllers, how asinine can you get?
